As noted in my commentary in the [referenced question][1], I do not think these should be permissible topics.
Legality is a tricky topic. Laws are often ambiguous, and they can vary quite significantly across regions of any size, including: cities, states, and countries. Firearms laws in particular can have many minute variations. e.g. concealed carry could be OK in a church in one town but not OK in the county surrounding that town
Firearms laws are also in a constant state of flux, particularly in the USA where we have significant lobbying interests trying to influence them constantly. This makes upkeep and accuracy of answers a significant maintenance headache.
Additionally, the Internet really isn't a good source of legal advice. The only _good_ and _correct_ answer to a question of legality should be, _"Ask your lawyer."_.
Finally, although I'm having difficulty finding specific examples, I believe topics of legality are traditionally voted off-topic on other StackExchange network sites.

In general, unless you're forbidden from copying material, then you should be able to cite the material in your answer. This always has the added benefit that if the link ever goes dead, the content will remain on the post. Furthermore, it is also simply a much greater convenience to future readers (who are the goal of the site to attract, after all) if they can get their answers in one place instead of having to follow links in every answer. A link-only answer should strive to instead have more information in the answer, but the link should remain as a citation.
If the entire material is too large or is otherwise unwieldy to place in an answer, then the most relevant portions should be kept in the post, possibly with additional flavor, and then the source can be linked for the entire read. Another common time to use links is to supplement an otherwise complete answer - sometimes an outside reference is very helpful to add. Regardless of the reasoning, *paraphrasing* the content of the link is also a good way to maintain the important information on our site while avoiding the issues that simply copy-paste would result it.

Great question!
Speaking as a moderator of another SE site I can shed some light on the convention for linking external resources.
* It is always desirable to include more than just a link to an external site.
The most obvious benefit here is that it preserves the answer on our site, obviating the need for a user to even navigate to the external resource. If a linked resources goes dead (all too common) then an answer with just a link becomes basically useless.
* Copy/paste of answers from external resources should be avoided.
Copying content from another resource is wrong. We need to be respectful of the author's copyright. Only if the content is explicitly released to the public domain should we copy information verbatim. Legality aside, not respecting an author's copyright is immoral.
A good answer should contain an actual answer to the question, links to resources that supplement the answer, and not be copied verbatim. If possible summarizing or paraphrasing the external resource should be done.
> If necessary small excerpts of the copyrighted work can be directly quoted as long as it is obvious that they are quotes, through the use of the block quote box.

What does the tag "safety" represent? I ask because I recently asked a question and tagged it "safety" because the question pertained to a (specific) gun's safety mechanism. Subsequently I noticed that all the other questions tagged as such were on the topic of being safe with firearms.
It doesn't matter to me a great deal, other than wanting to tag my own questions correctly. If the conventional wisdom says that the "safety" tag relates to safe gun handling, I might wish to remove that tag from my question.
What does the tag "safety" represent or does it not matter?

It seems that most people have used the safety tag to refer to safe gunhandling practices. However, this doesn't really leave an obvious, pithy tag to refer to mechanical safety mechanisms. One option might be to retag most of those questions "gun safety", leaving "safety" for the mechanism, but that seems to be going against what people expect.

As a rule of thumb, go with the shortest, clearest tag that describes the concept unambiguously. So for a firearms site, prefixes like "firearm-" and "gun-" are probably unnecessary...
...Except when they aren't. For instance, [safety could mean a couple of different things.](http://meta.firearms.stackexchange.com/questions/19/what-does-the-tag-safety-represent-or-does-it-not-matter)

Questions of legality are too often in flux for a static answer to remain relevant and correct. They are also too location-specific to be of general use. Do we want 50 posts, one for each state in the US, about whether it's legal to carry concealed in a restaurant that serves alcohol? For how long would any of those answers remain correct, if they were even correct to start with.
The bigger question is "what is the value of such an answer"? Can a community member act in reliance upon that information? Is the person answering the question an attorney? Will they cite case law?
It seems like every answer would have to start with "IANAL, but...." and end with "but be sure to check your local laws before doing X." What's the point?
I would vote to make these kinds of questions impermissible here.

Assumption of lethality in self-defense answers

I'm not sure what issue you're trying to address, but as a general rule, when shooting for self-defense, you want to "stop the threat". The best way to stop a threat is to completely disable the attacker.
If you merely injure an attacker, the threat may continue, which is undesirable.
If you totally disrupt the central nervous system or circulatory system of an attacker, it is unlikely that the threat will continue.
The issue of birdshot as an inadequate round for self-defense stems from the idea that it may only injure an attacker. If it lacks sufficient penetration to disrupt the central nervous system by severing the spine, or disrupt the circulatory system by stopping the heart, it is unlikely to completely stop a threat.

In your example, 7.62 by itself would certainly be ambiguous, as it could refer to x39 or x51 or x54r.
The general guideline is to use the shortest tag that clearly represents the concept.
I would propose 7.62×51 as the tag for this ammo.
To answer your specific question, I think it would be wise to create a set of standard "seed" tags for the most common ammo, but that an exhaustive list would be tedious to create.

Birdshot is a ridiculously poor choice for self-defense: someone amped up on drugs can take a round of it and keep coming at you.
If you are intent on using a firearm in a non-lethal way, you should not be using a shotgun, period. In theory, a suitably accurate pistol-wielder could shoot out an intruder's knees in a home defense situation. However, in my not-so-humble opinion: don't pull a gun if you aren't resigned to the fact that you may have to kill. Getting a clean shot at someone's knees requires that their knees be still enough, you have clear line of sight, and a whole bunch of other factors that may not be present.
If you feel that suggested answers to a question are focused on lethal approaches that may not be necessary, by all means offer your own answer. However, if you feel that *all* self-defense scenarios that require discharge of a firearm can be ended non-lethally, you are extrmely unrealistic in your expectations.

Legally speaking, using a firearm is deadly force. Even if your stated intent was only to wound someone, your justification for doing so will be judged in the context of deadly force.
As a practical matter, there are five ways to use a firearm to stop an attacker:
1. Fear 2. Pain 3. Destroy the brainstem 4. Sever the spinal cord above where it controls the hands 5. Lower the blood pressure to the brain by either (a) letting a lot of blood out or (b) destroying the heart.
Of these, only 3, 4, and 5 can be considered reliable against a determined attacker. These three are either certainly lethal (destroying the brainstem or the heart) or likely to be so (severing the spinal cord or massive blood loss).
The bottom line is any tactic, technique, or equipment for self defense with a firearm that will reliably stop a determined attacker is going to be potentially lethal.

A general principle of professional editing is to be careful not to change the original intent of the author. There are several "editors" on this SE site that use editing to change the original intent of questions and answers, to fit what they think is a better question or answer, sometimes without actually thinking about what the original intent was. In one case, the editor had to admit that he hadn't carefully read what he had changed.
The inclusion of a "rollback" feature is important because through the judicious use of the rollback, the original questioner or answerer can learn to improve the writing. When you edit a question to change the meaning, you are inserting your thoughts and this may not be what the author wanted to know. Seems to me that just because an author rewords something in response to your editing, it shouldn't be taken as an insult but as a positive thing. Your editing has educated the original writer. The person who directly causes the tag to be created is considered to have created the tag.
So whether you introduce a new tag to the site by posting a question with that tag on it, or by editing it into someone else's post, *you* created that tag. This is tracked independently of the actual posts the tag is on, so if the tag is later removed from the post on which it was introduced, the "creator" stays the same (with the exception of a tag that is removed from *all* posts and then automatically deleted by the system - at this point, it'll effectively be created anew upon its next use).
